author: pipermerriam

author: Deleted User
content: One question I am thinking about now is whether we want to change the CHAIN_ID after every ReGenesis event? It would mean that the transactions that did not make it into the chain before the event, will have to be explicitly recreated rather than failing on-chain due to lack of sufficient witnesses. I tend to say "yes"

author: djrtwo
content:
is the idea that this would happen in an automatic way in the consensus rules?
is it worth considering the addition of a `regen` counter to isolate the tx domain without modding the current chain_id usage?

author: Deleted User
content: no, I am now thinking that each ReGenesis event needs to be executed manually as a hard-fork, so we can justify our existence, and use it as an argument to get the difficulty bomb removed! ðŸ˜‰

author: djrtwo
content: lol. the state bloat bomb

author: Deleted User
content: exactly. And that is how I got to the changing CHAIN_ID

author: Deleted User
content: if someone wants to dissent, they can, and there is no replay attacks

author: djrtwo
content: My immediate intuition is to get it right and have it happen automatically, but I'm just catching up on regenesis today

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!291925846556540928> I've been thinking that the first one is manual and we go into it planning for the second one to institute it on a regular cadence

author: pipermerriam
content: (but those are some really loose thoughts, I'm guessing there are problems hiding)

author: djrtwo
content: and my most immediate concern while reading through is how this affects eth1+eth2 merger plans. thinking this is pretty opaque to the eth2 consensus layer as the merger is currently designed so that's good

author: djrtwo
content: meaning, regenesis is a part of the entire unified consensus rules of the aggregate system but the clean separation of eth1/eth2 (user-layer/consensus) just means that the calls to eth1 from eth2 just require calling the correct regenesis'd version

author: djrtwo
content: (this is all obvious, but just sanity checked it today)

author: djrtwo
content: <@456226577798135808> what would you suggest target active state size is? and what regenesis time interval does that dictate?

author: Deleted User
content: Target active state should be chosen so that you can get it fit in RAM on contemporary computers

author: Deleted User
content: that is why I though to have events scheduled manually, because it is impossible for the chain to know that

author: djrtwo
content: we can understand worst case bounds based on gas limit and block time

author: Deleted User
content: yes, but chain does not know how much RAM is normally in the computers ðŸ™‚

author: djrtwo
content:

so 6GB (8GB RAM with some room to spare?)

content:
> yes, but chain does not know how much RAM is normally in the computers ðŸ™‚

but a regular cadence for 4 years then a slog of a political campaign for a 2x regenesis based on RAM advancements could also be a path...

author: Deleted User
content: yes, I think both being too conservative and too aggressive is not good

author: Deleted User
content: who has 6Gb on their computers these days? I thought it was more like 16 or 32

author: djrtwo
content:
wife was just looking at lenovo Yoga yesterday which maxes at 8GB
definitely depends on what type of consumer hardware we want to be able to run ethereum (or in the context of shards, a full-active-state single shard _in memory_)

author: djrtwo
content: sometimes there's talk of being able to use the old laptop youhave laying around as a dedicated node

author: djrtwo
content: in that case, you have to subtract ~4 years from the RAM race

author: djrtwo
content: (I don't suggest my wife buys the Yoga. 8GB sounds terrible in the world of browser tabs)

author: Deleted User
content: yes, that's fair i guess. doing ReGenesis too often has usability downsides, but we can try to find a good balance

author: djrtwo
content: right

author: djrtwo
content: would you say the state trie migration is a pre-req to regenesis?

author: Deleted User
content: not necessarily, but we need to produce some data

author: djrtwo
content: We still have the max block size with witnesses problem with regenesis, right?

author: Deleted User
content: no, this is much easier to handle

author: Deleted User
content: because most witnesses come with transactions, not blocks

author: Deleted User
content: and the large ones can be knocked out in the tx pool

author: Deleted User
content: but the blocks after regenesis maybe large

author: Deleted User
content: and that is why we might need to do trie migration

author: Deleted User
content: we need backtesting to see how quickly block size increase due to witnesses will fall after Regenesis event

author: djrtwo
content: right, I see

author: Deleted User
content: oh, and if we manage to do pre-consensus, then the large blocks won't matter so much, because everyone will know most of the block that will be mined, the only difference is the coinbase ðŸ™‚

author: Deleted User
content: I will include this into the doc as well

author: djrtwo
content: pre-consensus?

author: Deleted User
content: so instead of propagating large blocks over, we will be propagating miner's coinbases + headers

author: Deleted User
content: https://ledgerwatch.github.io/regenesis_plan.html#Pre-consensus-network

author: Deleted User
content: even without pre-consensus, if we simply make the block a sequence of tx IDs instead of listing all tx with all their witnesses (which by that time have already gotten everywhere), it should make large block problem easier

author: Deleted User
content: this is sort of "thin block" optimisation known for ages ðŸ™‚

author: Deleted User
content: this is actually what will incentivise miners to follow pre-consensus rather than ignoring it

author: Deleted User
content: because pre-consensus blocks can propagate faster

author: djrtwo
content: _who_ is coming to pre-consensus on blocks?

author: Deleted User
content: all the nodes. The miners can choose to obey or not

author: djrtwo
content: is there sibel resistance here?

author: Deleted User
content: well, this is what I am going to find out very soon. I am assuming that Avalanche is a good fit for such pre-consensus, but we will see

author: djrtwo
content: avalanche at least requires a tokens in their consensus mechanism for baseline sibel resistance

author: djrtwo
content: so in eth2, you could imagine leveraging the validator set in a sub-consensus but not exactly sure how that'd look here

author: .vbuterin
content: aah just realized this channel exists

author: .vbuterin
content: copying my questions from the other channel

author: .vbuterin
content:
One question about the regenesis model: how does it work between three epochs? That is, suppose you're currently in epoch N, and you're trying to access an account that was last modified during epoch N-2. Do you (i) need to provide both a witness for epoch N-2 and a witness for epoch N-1 to prove no subsequent change, or (ii) is there some crazy merge process when epoch N-1 ends that combines together the two states, or (iii) something else?
Another question: are accounts that are in the inactive state (i) required to be part of an access list, or (ii) could tx execution unexpectedly trigger a requirement to access some particular account that has not been modifed in a long time?
If the answers are (i) and (i), then this is remarkably similar to rent models from 1-2 years ago ðŸ˜›
Except I guess with discrete epochs instead of continuous

author: pipermerriam
content: I believe the model doesn't care about historical epochs and only differentiates between active/inactive.  Everything from **any** old epoch is inactive and the network only cares that transactions/blocks provide a proof for that data against any stateroot on or after the most recent epoch(regenesis) boundary.

author: pipermerriam
content: Similarity with state-rent is..... sneaky ... and I like it ... because it does state rent via the indirect mechanism of transaction fees.

author: .vbuterin
content: right, but I mean to prove inactive state from more than one epoch ago

author: .vbuterin
content: you either need multiple merkle proofs, or you need some kind of merge process

author: pipermerriam
content: I don't think so.  At re-genesis boundary the state root stays the same, but everything gets moved to inactive state.  I'm not following why multiple proofs would be needed (which I'm reasonably confident is not the case)

author: .vbuterin
content: okay, so suppose that:

author: .vbuterin
content: the state at the end of epoch 1 is S

author: .vbuterin
content: so at the beginning of epoch 2, the inactive state is S, and the active state is {}

author: .vbuterin
content: correct so far?

author: .vbuterin
content: then at the end of epoch 2, the active state becomes S'

author: .vbuterin
content: Now, suppose that, during epoch 3, you are trying to prove the state of some account that was last modified in epoch 1

author: .vbuterin
content: let's say the account is x and the value is y

author: .vbuterin
content: you have to prove that (i) S[x] = y and (ii) x not in S'

author: .vbuterin
content: unless at the end of epoch 2 you somehow merge S and S'

author: .vbuterin
content: into a single tree

author: .vbuterin
content: which would be an O(N) operation

author: pipermerriam
content: I think this is where regenesis shines, because the network doesn't care about anything other than the active/inactive distinction.  After a few epochs we would have a few snapshots and it becomes the transaction sender's problem of constructing a merkle proof against the most recent re-genesis state root.  The network treats them as if they've been merged, the transaction producers are free to solve the problem however they choose.

author: .vbuterin
content: but there has to be some canonical way of representing the state roots.....

author: pipermerriam
content: I think the state root mechanism stays the same as it does today, but the client tracks only the active state, and any attempt to access inactive state terminates execution.

author: .vbuterin
content: aaah I see, there's no actual state root separation

author: pipermerriam
content: right

author: .vbuterin
content: ok, so the best metaphor then is not rent, it's partial-statelessness

author: .vbuterin
content: and there are zero consensus changes, it's all a higher-layer thing

author: pipermerriam
content: yeah, lots of good metaphors for us to use, purge, cleaning house, ...

author: .vbuterin
content: but it's not a "purge" per se in that the state isn't being purged from "the chain", it's being purged from what some clients store

author: .vbuterin
content: (I'm sure there will be clients that keep just storing the full state)

author: pipermerriam
content: right, it's being purged from the concern of the network

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Itâ€™s like RAM and hard drive?

author: pipermerriam
content: inactive state doesn't need the high speed access that active state does, so it makes a lot of sense to store them on different mediums.  Ideally we end up seeing some sort of decentralized network that shards and distributes the inactive state or something like that.
